concept.title: What are PivotTables?
concept.shortdesc: A short introduction to PivotTables, their possibilities, and what components it has.

conbody.p: A PivotTable is used when a variable should be plotted against another variable. With PivotTables you can get answers to questions like what product provides the highest profit contribution; which seller makes the highest turnover; which department incurs the most costs; etc.

If the data is well organized in an Excel worksheet then you can quickly plot data against each other with a PivotTable. In the following figure, you can easily compare the sales in the three product categories. This is because a PivotTable is interactive. You can always change the view of the data to see more details or to make other summaries.

In PivotTables, at least two types of data are plotted against each other. For example productcategory against town. One data type is presented in the column field (productcategory) and the other one in the row field (town). Another data type from which you want to see the results (Sales) has to be put in the values field. Because these results are summarized you should also indicate which calculation method should be used (here Sum). The function Sum is given by default. Other possibilities are Count, Average, Min, Max, Product, Stdev, Stdevp, Var, Varp.
A PivotTable has four areas in which you can place fields:

strow.stentry: The fields with numeric information you want to summarize, usually for the calculation of totals and averages.
These fields are used to create separate groups and put the information for each group in a separate row.

These fields are also used to create separate groups. Mostly used if you want to subdivide the data into the rows. These groups are displayed in separate columns. Take fields with not too many groups, otherwise, the table will come too wide.
These fields can be used for filtering the data.
